Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogenetic systematics, lineage diversification, and niche evolution in spinetails (Furnariidae, Aves)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Determining the how species are created is key to understanding the origins and maintenance of biodiversity across the planet. This project tackles this issue by focusing on a small set of very similar tropical birds called "spinetails", which are unusual because they appear to have developed new species at an incredibly fast rate. If this rapid speciation is indeed the case, study of spinetails will likely reveal novel insights about how new species come about. Investigators will use genetic techniques and cutting-edge statistical analyses to determine the evolutionary history of spinetails. The study will foster international partnerships through sharing of genetic samples and collaborating on complicated analyses of huge genetic datasets. The study will also provide research opportunities for undergraduates interested in learning how to apply bioinformatics and statistical programming to answer fundamental questions in ecology and evolutionary biology. Results of this study will help resolve long-standing taxonomic confusion about spinetails and provide a clearer picture of South American biodiversity -- a goal of both science and conservation.

Specifically, the investigators will test two alternative hypotheses of speciation. Both hypotheses rely on geographic isolation as a key requirement and explore the ecological context in which populations become isolated. On the one hand, if two populations of the same species occur in different environments it may cause to them to diverge ecologically due to local adaptation. Alternatively, small environmental differences may exist within a species' distribution due to conserved ecological preferences. If this distribution is divided by a region outside the species' ecological preference, such as mountains for a lowland species, dispersal will be greatly restricted. These hypotheses will be tested at multiple evolutionary scales. Across Furnariidae, there is a positive relationship between the rate of ecological divergence and speciation. Importantly, the arboreal spinetails (genus Cranioleuca) exhibit rates of ecological divergence and speciation far exceeding those found in other groups in the family. Both observations support the hypothesis that ecological divergence is associated with speciation, but to test these hypotheses a densely sampled phylogeny is needed. This study will reconstruct the evolutionary relationships of the arboreal spinetails using genomic scale genetic datasets. Investigators will then employ detailed comparative analyses to determine if speciation in this group is associated with ecological divergence or conservatism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the Origin of Species, Darwin observed that the various species of Galapagos Finches differed from one another in the size and shape of their bills and thus the foods they ate. That is, the species occupied different niches. This suggested to Darwin that speciation is coupled to niche divergence. Across large groups of related species, this hypothesis predicts that the degree of niche divergence seen with a group should be related to the number of species in that group. Within a single species, niche divergence may drive drive speciation by reducing gene flow among populations occupying different environments. Much progress has been made testing these predictions in many different groups of organisms, but there remains a lack of studies addressing the role of the niche in diversification at different time scales within the same lineage. For this project, we used the Neotropical bird radiation of ovenbirds, woodcreepers, leaftossers and miners (Passeriformes: Furnariidae) as a model system to examine the role of niche evolution in speciation and lineage diversification.

Most studies of niche evolution in diversification have focused on morphology, given its clear importance to niche divergence at small spatial scales (i.e. where a bird forages). At larger spatial scales, species may diverge in climatic tolerances (the climatic-niche), which is seen in different habitat preferences (i.e. rainforest vs. desert). Morphology and the climatic-niche constitute alternative spatial scales at which a species niche can be quantified. However, studies of the role of niche evolution in diversification have generally focused on morphological diversification, despite a growing appreciation for the role of climatic-niche divergence during speciation. We tested these alternatives using morphological and climatic-niche data from 298 species of ovenbirds (Aves: Furnariidae). We examined correlations between rates of niche evolution and diversification rate across independent groups in the family.

We found that within Furnariidae, the degree of divergence in a group’s climatic-niche was a better predictor of their biodiversity than their degree of morphological divergence. Although both are clearly important, our analyses consistently supported the climatic-niche as the best predictor of biodiversity. This study adds to the growing body of evidence suggesting that the climatic-niche may be an important driver of biodiversity in addition to morphology.

Broad scale correlations between niche evolution and diversification, although interesting, cannot reveal underlying processes. For this, it is crucial to understand the causes of morphological and genetic differentiation within species, as these are the principal ingredients of speciation. One possibility is that a positive correlation between genetic differentiation and morphological differentiation, which would support a role for niche evolution in speciation. Alternatively, the amount of genetic differentiation between populations could decrease as the geographic distance between them increases with genetic differences due simply to distance. We compared these two alternatives in a dramatic case of continuous morphological variation in an Andean songbird, the Line-cheeked Spinetail (Cranioleuca antisiensis). This species nearly triples its body size from north to south with considerable plumage differentiation. We analyzed morhpological, environmental, and genetic data from 172 individuals and 19 populations across the species’ linear distribution.

         We found that body size in C. antisiensis was tightly correlated with decreasing temperatures, consistent with local adaptation as per Bergmann’s Rule. We found further support for the body size cline’s adaptive provenance with a test for natural selection. However, we did not find evidence that natural selection resulted in the plumage cline. We found that geographic distance was, by far, the best explanation for genetic differentiation along the cline. Natural selection has been shown to reduce gene flow and taken as widespread evidence of the niche’s role in diversification. We challenge this view by demonstrating that although natural selection is important in generating adaptive morphological divergence in C. antisiensis, its role in structuring genetic variation is limited.

The components of our study have contributed to our understanding of how the incredible diversity of the tropics came to be. It also sheds llight on the role niche evolution in diversification and provides novel analytical techniques for use by future researchers.
